title: How to Grow Strawberry Runners With Big Root Balls

steps.headline: Assemble the supplies needed.
steps.description: Check the "Things You'll Need" list below.

steps.headline: Use scissors to remove the bottom of the chosen flower pot.
steps.description: Make a slot near the upper end.

steps.headline: Select a runner.
steps.description: Choose the first one from the mother plant. Cut away the stem to the next runner.

steps.headline: Shift the runner aside.
steps.description: Use a bulb planter to make it easier to put the flower pot in the soil––use it to make a round hole in the garden soil, about 6 inches (15cm) deep and 4 inches (10cm) wide. Wiggle or open the planter in the soil to make a wider hole.

steps.headline: Take the bulb planter with garden earth out of the soil.
Put a bottomless flower pot in the hole in the soil.
steps.description: Turn the slot of the pot towards the mother strawberry plant.

steps.headline: Strew some manure or compost into the hole.
steps.description: Strew some earth from the bulb planter into the hole. Then strew some more manure or compost into the hole. Then strew the rest of the earth from the bulb planter into the hole. Press gently on the earth in the pot. Add some garden earth in the hole when desired.

steps.headline: Lay the runner on the earth in the flower pot.
steps.description: Fix the runner in the slot.

steps.headline: Water the runner and the soil in the flower pot.
Use a scoop to dig out the flower pot with the strawberry plant and root ball.
Cut the sidewall of the flower pot and take the plant out.
Use a scoop to make a big hole in the soil.
steps.description: Strew some manure or compost in the hole when desired.

steps.headline: Take the root ball of the big runner in one hand and keep it at the right position in the hole.
steps.description: Use your other hand to shove garden earth underneath and around the root ball of the plant. Plant the runner at the right height in the soil. The upper side of the root ball must be at the same height as the upper side of the garden soil.

steps.headline: Plant all runners in the garden.

text: Preparing the Materials Assemble the supplies needed. Check the "Things You'll Need" list below. Use scissors to remove the bottom of the chosen flower pot. Make a slot near the upper end. Fixing the Runners Select a runner. Choose the first one from the mother plant. Cut away the stem to the next runner. Shift the runner aside. Use a bulb planter to make it easier to put the flower pot in the soil––use it to make a round hole in the garden soil, about 6 inches (15cm) deep and 4 inches (10cm) wide. Wiggle or open the planter in the soil to make a wider hole. Take the bulb planter with garden earth out of the soil.  Put a bottomless flower pot in the hole in the soil. Turn the slot of the pot towards the mother strawberry plant. Strew some manure or compost into the hole. Strew some earth from the bulb planter into the hole. Then strew some more manure or compost into the hole. Then strew the rest of the earth from the bulb planter into the hole. Press gently on the earth in the pot. Add some garden earth in the hole when desired. Lay the runner on the earth in the flower pot. Fix the runner in the slot. Water the runner and the soil in the flower pot.  Taking out Big Runners Use a scoop to dig out the flower pot with the strawberry plant and root ball.  Cut the sidewall of the flower pot and take the plant out.  Planting Big Runners Use a scoop to make a big hole in the soil. Strew some manure or compost in the hole when desired. Take the root ball of the big runner in one hand and keep it at the right position in the hole. Use your other hand to shove garden earth underneath and around the root ball of the plant. Plant the runner at the right height in the soil. The upper side of the root ball must be at the same height as the upper side of the garden soil. Plant all runners in the garden.
